column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=II
#Text=For more than two years Eric Hermannson kept the austere faith to which he had sworn himself , kept it until a girl from the East came to spend a week on the Nebraska Divide .
#Text=She was a girl of other manners and conditions , and there were greater distances between her life and Eric 's than all the miles which separated Rattlesnake Creek from New York City .
#Text=Indeed , she had no business to be in the West at all ; but ah ! across what leagues of land and sea , by what improbable chances , do the unrelenting gods bring to us our fate !
#Text=It was in a year of financial depression that Wyllis Elliot came to Nebraska to buy cheap land and revisit the country where he had spent a year of his youth .

#Text=When he had graduated from Harvard it was still customary for moneyed gentlemen to send their scapegrace sons to rough it on ranches in the wilds of Nebraska or Dakota , or to consign them to a living death in the sagebrush of the Black Hills .
#Text=These young men did not always return to the ways of civilized life .
#Text=But Wyllis Elliot had not married a half-breed , nor been shot in a cowpunchers ' brawl , nor wrecked by bad whisky , nor appropriated by a smirched adventuress .

#Text=He had been saved from these things by a girl , his sister , who had been very near to his life ever since the days when they read fairy tales together and dreamed the dreams that never come true .
#Text=On this , his first visit to his father 's ranch since he left it six years before , he brought her with him .
#Text=She had been laid up half the winter from a sprain received while skating , and had had too much time for reflection during those months .
#Text=She was restless and filled with a desire to see something of the wild country of which her brother had told her so much .

#Text=She was to be married the next winter , and Wyllis understood her when she begged him to take her with him on this long , aimless jaunt across the continent , to taste the last of their freedom together .
#Text=It comes to all women of her type -- that desire to taste the unknown which allures and terrifies , to run one 's whole soul 's length out to the wind -- just once .
#Text=It had been an eventful journey .
#Text=Wyllis somehow understood that strain of gypsy blood in his sister , and he knew where to take her .

#Text=They had slept in sod houses on the Platte River , made the acquaintance of the personnel of a third-rate opera company on the train to Deadwood , dined in a camp of railroad constructors at the world 's end beyond New Castle , gone through the Black Hills on horseback , fished for trout in Dome Lake , watched a dance at Cripple Creek , where the lost souls who hide in the hills gathered for their besotted revelry .

#Text=And now , last of all , before the return to thraldom , there was this little shack , anchored on the windy crest of the Divide , a little black dot against the flaming sunsets , a scented sea of cornland bathed in opalescent air and blinding sunlight .

#Text=Margaret Elliot was one of those women of whom there are so many in this day , when old order , passing , giveth place to new ; beautiful , talented , critical , unsatisfied , tired of the world at twenty-four .
#Text=For the moment the life and people of the Divide interested her .
#Text=She was there but a week ; perhaps had she stayed longer , that inexorable ennui which travels faster even than the Vestibule Limited would have overtaken her .
#Text=The week she tarried there was the week that Eric Hermannson was helping Jerry Lockhart thresh ; a week earlier or a week later , and there would have been no story to write .
#Text=It was on Thursday and they were to leave on Saturday .

#Text=Wyllis and his sister were sitting on the wide piazza of the ranchhouse , staring out into the afternoon sunlight and protesting against the gusts of hot wind that blew up from the sandy riverbottom twenty miles to the southward .
#Text=The young man pulled his cap lower over his eyes and remarked :
#Text=“ This wind is the real thing ; you do n't strike it anywhere else .
#Text=You remember we had a touch of it in Algiers and I told you it came from Kansas .
#Text=It 's the keynote of this country . ”
#Text=Wyllis touched her hand that lay on the hammock and continued gently :
#Text=“ I hope it 's paid you , Sis .
#Text=Roughing it 's dangerous business ; it takes the taste out of things . ”
#Text=She shut her fingers firmly over the brown hand that was so like her own .
#Text=“ Paid ?
#Text=Why , Wyllis , I have n't been so happy since we were children and were going to discover the ruins of Troy together some day .
#Text=Do you know , I believe I could just stay on here forever and let the world go on its own gait .
#Text=It seems as though the tension and strain we used to talk of last winter were gone for good , as though one could never give one 's strength out to such petty things any more . ”
#Text=Wyllis brushed the ashes of his pipe away from the silk handkerchief that was knotted about his neck and stared moodily off at the skyline .
